explanation:
int32: Determine whether this is a plain typedef (e.g. to a standard integral type) or a compiler-specific extended type. If it is a compiler builtin or uses non‑standard width specifiers that are compiler extensions, that would violate the rule.

os_err_name_t: The code treats *err_name as an array object (uses sizeof(*err_name), indexing and passes it to strncpy/snprintf). We must know if os_err_name_t is an array typedef (char name[N]), a pointer type, or a compiler‑specific type (e.g. GCC extension typedefs). Array/typedef details affect whether expressions rely on array-to-pointer decay or other non‑standard behavior.

OS_ErrorTable_Entry_t: Need the struct definition to see the types of .Name and .Number. If .Name is declared with a flexible/zero-length array, unnamed members, or uses compiler attributes/extension syntax (e.g. GCC zero-length arrays, attribute((...))), that would be an extension.

OS_GLOBAL_ERROR_NAME_TABLE and OS_IMPL_ERROR_NAME_TABLE: Need their declarations/definitions to see their types (array, pointer) and any storage attributes (section attributes, alignment, visibility) that might use compiler extensions (e.g. __attribute__((section(...)))) which are language/compiler extensions.

OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH: Required to check buffer-size constants and to confirm indexing/sizeof usages are standard; also to detect if this macro/constant is implemented using an expression or extension macro that would be non‑standard.

OS_CHECK_POINTER: This macro is invoked in the function; its expansion may use compiler builtin extensions (e.g. __builtin_expect, __attribute__, statement expressions, or non‑standard control flow). Need its definition to ensure it does not rely on language extensions.

OS_SUCCESS and OS_ERROR: Need their definitions to ensure they are plain constants (enum/integer macros) and not implemented via compiler‑specific constructs.

OS_printf: OS_CHECK_POINTER or other macros might call or wrap OS_printf; OS_printf itself may be implemented with variadic macros, inline assembly, or compiler extensions. Inspecting its declaration/definition rules out use of extensions.

strncpy and snprintf: Although standard library functions, they may be #defined/wrapped by project macros or inline wrappers that use compiler extensions (variadic macros, inline asm, statement expressions). Confirming their actual declarations/definitions ensures no hidden extension is used by these calls.

In summary: the above symbols (typedefs, struct/variable definitions, macros and the few constants/functions touched) must be inspected to determine whether any non‑standard compiler/language extensions are used in the types, macro expansions, or declarations referenced by OS_GetErrorName.
